Peterson | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|4|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Denton, Texas|Denton]], [[Texas]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|1|25|1935|4|23|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Smyrna, Tennessee|Smyrna]], [[Tennessee]], U.S. | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Traditional popular music|Traditional pop]], [[country music|country]], [[rock and roll]], [[rockabilly]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]] | years_active = 1958–2004 | label = [[RCA Victor]], Dunes Records | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Ray Peterson''' (April 23, 1935 – January 25, 2005) was an American [[pop music|pop]] [[singing|singer]] who is best remembered for singing "[[Tell Laura I Love Her]]". He also scored numerous other hits, including "[[Corrine, Corrina]]" and "[[The Wonder of You]]".{{Cite news |last=Press |first=The Associated |date=2005-01-29 |title=Ray Peterson, Singer Known for His 'Tell Laura I Love Her,' Dies at 65 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/29/arts/music/ray-peterson-singer-known-for-his-tell-laura-i-love-her-dies-at.html |access-date=2024-08-07 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} ==Life and career== Ray T. Peterson was born in [[Denton, Texas]] on April 23, 1935. At the time of his death, sources gave 1939 as his year of birth.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2005/feb/01/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries1|title=Obituary: Ray Peterson|first=Dave|last=Laing|date=1 February 2005|access-date=4 December 2017|website=The Guardian}} As a boy he had [[poliomyelitis|polio]]. Having a four-[[octave]] singing [[human voice|voice]], Peterson moved to [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], where he was signed to a [[recording contract]] with [[RCA Victor]] in 1958. He [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] several songs that were minor [[hit record|hits]] until "[[The Wonder of You]]" made it into the [[Top 40]] of the ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] [[record chart|chart]] on June 15, 1959. The song also did well in Australia, stopping at #9 on its chart. The song would later be recorded by [[Elvis Presley]], with whom Peterson became friends. Peterson scored a [[Top 40|Top 10]] hit with the [[teenage tragedy song]], "[[Tell Laura I Love Her]]".#7 on June 27, 1960 In the UK, [[Decca Records]] made the decision not to release the latter recording on the grounds that it was "too tasteless and vulgar," and destroyed about twenty thousand copies that had already been pressed. A cover version by [[Ricky Valance]], released by [[EMI]] on the [[Columbia Graphophone Company|Columbia]] label, was Number One on the [[UK Singles Chart]] for three weeks.{{cite book | first= Jo | last= Rice | year= 1982 | title= The Guinness Book of 500 Number One Hits | edition= 1st | publisher= Guinness Superlatives Ltd | location= Enfield, Middlesex | page= 53 | isbn= 0-85112-250-7}}{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=13087|title=Tell Laura I Love Her by Ray Peterson Songfacts|website=Songfacts.com|access-date=4 December 2017}} In 1960, Peterson created his own [[record label]] with his [[management|manager]] Stan Shulman, called Dunes Records, and enlisted the help of [[record producer]] [[Phil Spector]]{{cite web|url=http://www.rockabillyhall.com/RayPeterson1.html|title=RAB Hall of Fame: Ray Peterson|website=Rockabillyhall.com|access-date=4 December 2017|archive-date=15 January 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200115174136/http://www.rockabillyhall.com/RayPeterson1.html|url-status=dead}} with "[[Corrine, Corrina]]".#9 on December 19, 1960; produced by Spector; cover of a 1931 [[Red Nichols]] hit Peterson's dramatic [[ballad]], "I Could Have Loved You So Well", [[songwriter|written]] by [[Barry Mann]] and [[Gerry Goffin]]{{cite web|url=http://mann-weil.com/music_discography.php?s=ghi#72|title=Barry Mann & Cynthia Weil - Official Website - Music - Discography|website=Mann-weil.com|access-date=4 December 2017}} and produced by Spector,{{citation needed|date=January 2021}} only reached #57 on the U.S. chart.{{Cite magazine|title=Ray Peterson. I Could Have Loved You So Well|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/ray-peterson/chart-history/hsi/|access-date=2021-01-21|magazine=Billboard}} He then tried another [[death disc]], "Give Us Your Blessing", but this time the record only made #70 in the Hot-100. (The later song was covered by [[the Shangri-Las]] five years later and became a Top 30 hit.) His last charting US-Top-30 hit was "[[Missing You (Red Sovine song)|Missing You]]".#29 on June 29, 1961 By the mid-1960s he had become something of a phenomenon on the west coast of the United States, appearing live in numerous [[concert]]s with Keith Allison. His performances at the Sacramento Memorial Auditorium, produced by [[Fred Vail]], beginning in 1963 helped fuel a revival of "The Wonder of You", as well as launching his new relationship with [[MGM Records]], an alliance that produced two [[albums]]: ''The Very Best of Ray Peterson'' which featured most of the Dunes singles, and ''The Other Side of Ray Peterson,'' which included many of his [[nightclub]] songs. He later moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]], and by the 1970s when the hit records stopped coming, Peterson became a [[Baptist Church]] [[religious minister|minister]] and occasionally played the classic hits music circuit. In 1981 he released a Christian folk rock album called ''Highest Flight'', which was also released as ''My Father's Place''. Peterson was inducted into the [[Rockabilly Hall of Fame]]. Peterson died of colon cancer on January 25, 2005, in [[Smyrna, Tennessee]], aged 69.{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p11407/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Jason Ankeny |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=March 29, 2009}} He left a [[widow]], four sons, and three daughters. For publicity reasons, he had shaved four years off his age, leading many sources to list his age as 65.
